## Exercise 1

### Trainsition Matrix :

\begin{align*}
  P=
  \begin{pmatrix}
    &1/2& 1/2& 0& \\
    &1/2& 1/4&  1/4& \\ 
    &0& 1/3& 2/3&\\
  \end{pmatrix}
\end{align*}

### Trainsition Diagram : 

\begin{figure}[ht]
\centering
   \includegraphics[width=10cm]{example1.png}
   \hfil
\caption{Example 1 Trainsition Diagram}

\vspace{20pt}

### Remark
* A state $i$ is said to be recurrent if, starting from $i$, the probability of getting back to $i$ is 1 

* A state $i$ is said to be trainsient if, starting from $i$, the probability of getting back to $i$ is less than 1 

recurrent state :{1,2,3} ,All states communicate, all states recurrent

## Exercise 2

### Trainsition Matrix :

\begin{align*}
  P=
  \begin{pmatrix}
    &1 & 0& 0& \\
    &1/4& 1/2&  1/4& \\ 
    &0& 0& 1\\
  \end{pmatrix}
\end{align*}

### Trainsition Diagram : 

\begin{figure}[ht]
\centering
   \includegraphics[width=10cm]{example2.png}
   \hfil
\caption{Example 2 Trainsition Diagram}
\label{Figure 2.}
\end{figure}

\vspace{20pt}

### Remark
* A state $i$ is said to be recurrent if, starting from $i$, the probability of getting back to $i$ is 1 

* A state $i$ is said to be trainsient if, starting from $i$, the probability of getting back to $i$ is less than 1 

* A state $i$ is said to be abosrbing state, as a special case of reccurent state, if $P_{ii}=1$ (You can naver leave the state $i$ if you get there) 



recurrent state : {1,3}

trainsient state : {2} 

abosrbing state : {1,3}
